Graphical abstract Among industrial applications of CO2, the formation of cyclic carbonates from epoxides offers relevant chemical potentialities. Here, various N,N-dimethyl-N-cetyl-N-(2-hydroxyethyl)ammonium salts (HEA16X) associated with different counter-anions (X−) have been investigated as catalysts of the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide to styrene oxide. Most of these salts were characterized by reasonable catalytic activities in benzonitrile at 120°C and under 15bar of CO2 compared to choline chloride and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide. The influence of three parameters has been studied: (i) the polar head group, (ii) the anion (I−, Br−, Cl− for halogens and HCO3 −, mesylate (Ms−), triflate (Tf−)) in the HEA16X series, as well as (iii) the chain length. The higher conversion and selectivity obtained with HEA16Br, compared to CTABr, pointed out the beneficial contribution of the hydroxylated polar head. The role of the compensation anion or more exactly of its nucleophilicity on the catalyst activity was also shown. However, unexpected results with HCO3 −, affording styrene oxide conversions up to 95% (better than with HEA16Cl), were also obtained. DFT calculations supported the beneficial influence of the 2-hydroxyethyl substituent and the unexpected reactivity of the ammonium hydrogenocarbonate, HEA16HCO3. The reaction profiles allowed to draw some correlations (i) between styrene oxide conversion and the relative energy of the first intermediate and (ii) between the styrene carbonate selectivity and the energy of the first transition state. A new and original mechanism was also proposed for the reaction catalyzed by ammonium hydrogenocarbonate. Keywords 2-Hydroxyethyl substituted quaternary ammonium salts Styrene oxide/CO2 coupling reaction Reaction profiles Nucleophilicity Hydrogenocarbonate 1 Introduction The greenhouse gases concentration in the atmosphere is predicted to rise by 25–90% between 2000 and 2030 [1]. Such an increase resulting from the growing energetic demand is considered to be the main cause of global warming [2]. Carbon dioxide is the predominant greenhouse gas so its mitigation remains one of the greatest environmental challenges of our times. The use of this widely available, cheap and non-toxic resource of carbon as a chemical feedstock could provide a way to produce valuable products. Significant efforts must be performed to achieve this goal. Indeed, in 2010, CO2 industrial applications, excluding use for enhanced oil recovery, represented only 0.5% (120milliontons a year) of the total anthropogenic CO2 emissions [3]. The main industrial applications of CO2 as a chemical feedstock concern the production of (i) urea (100milliontons a year) [4], (ii) methanol from natural gas with a small amount of CO2 (additive to CO) [3], (iii) organic carbonates [5] and (iv) carboxylic acids, mainly salicylic acid [6]. Among them, a promising process is the formation of cyclic carbonates. In this latter example, CO2 replaces phosgene (COCl2) as the C1 building unit. Due to their high boiling point, organic carbonates are often used as polar and aprotic solvents [7]. Cyclic carbonates find many applications in the chemical industry [8], such as, for instance, paint-strippers [9], components of lithium batteries [10] as well as in medicinal chemistry [11]. Furthermore, they are interesting chemical intermediates [12] in the formation of carbamates that can be converted later into polyurethanes [13]. Many homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts involving either metallic or non-metallic active phases have been developed to synthesize cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides. The use of organic bases [14,15], zeolites [16,17], metal oxides [18–20], metal halides [21–23], metal complexes [24–26], ionic liquids [27–29] and more generally quaternary ammonium or phosphonium salts [30,31–35] is well-documented [36]. Up to now, best performances under mild conditions (low temperature and pressure) are obtained with catalyst systems based on transition metal complexes often coupled with nucleophilic co-catalysts such as quaternary ammonium halides [37,38]. Already implemented alone in industrial processes, quaternary ammonium salts (QAS) work rather in drastic conditions of CO2 pressure (30–80bar) and temperature (120–160°C) [31]. The role of QAS in the formation of cyclic carbonates is related to the nucleophilic attack of the oxirane ring by their counter-anion [36] and it is now generally admitted that a complementary activation of the epoxides through hydrogen bonding can improve their catalytic activity [39–42]. Using DFT calculations, a mechanism supporting the role of hydrogen bonding has been proposed for a model system consisting in Bu4NBr or Bu4NI and several additives such as alcohols, carboxylic acids and water [40,43,44]. Hydroxyl-functionalized ionic liquids, including deep eutectic solvents based on choline chloride, and hydroxyl-functionalized quaternary ammonium or phosphonium salts were experimented successfully by different research groups [29,31,32,34,35,45,46]. However, most of the corresponding publications did not combine theoretical and experimental results or when they did, very few examples were considered. That is why we undertook a systematic study based on a whole series of hydroxylated quaternary ammonium salts, precisely N-cetyl-N,N-dimethyl-N-(2-hydroxyethyl)ammonium salts (HEA16X) with a large variety of counter-anions including non-halogenated ones (Fig. 1 a; I−, Br−, Cl−, HCO3 −, mesylate (Ms−), triflate (Tf−)) [47,48]. In the present work, all of them were used as organocatalysts in the styrene oxide/CO2 coupling reaction (Scheme 1 ). The catalytic activities of all these salts have been compared with those of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide [49,50] (CTABr, Fig. 1b) and choline chloride [29,45,51] (HEA1Cl, Fig. 1c), used as reference QAS. Our attention will be focused on the influence of (i) the polar head group (keeping the counter-anion (Br−) and the chain length (C16H33) constant (CTABr vs. HEA16Br)), (ii) the anion (I−, Br−, Cl− for halogens and HCO3 −, mesylate (Ms−), triflate (Tf−)) keeping the polar head group (NCH2 CH2 OH)+ and the chain length (C16H33-) constant (HEA16X catalysts) and (iii) the chain length (from CH3- in choline chloride to C16H33- in HEA16Cl) on the catalytic activity, selectivity and catalyst recycling ability. Hence, our work will allow to study, for one set of conditions, more parameters than the sole influence of the alkyl chains of the QAS already done in the case of tetraalkyl ammonium salts [50,52]. This thorough experimental study will be completed by a theoretical one based on the use of density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Results of the latter will be exploited in order to elucidate the influence of the catalyst nature and structure on the styrene oxide/CO2 coupling reaction mechanism and clarify the different reaction paths or intermediates formed in the presence of the several tested catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Styrene oxide (97%), n-dodecane (⩾99%), benzonitrile (99%), ethylbenzene (99%), propylene carbonate (⩾99%), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, ⩾98%) and choline chloride (HEA1Cl, ⩾98%) were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich and used as received. N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, ⩾99.8%) and ethyl acetate (⩾99.8%) were purchased from VWR and SDS, respectively. Carbon dioxide (99.9%) and nitrogen (99.995%) were supplied by Air Liquide. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis HEA16Cl (N,N-dimethyl-N-cetyl-N-(2-hydroxyethyl) ammonium chloride) was prepared as previously described by Roucoux et al. [47,48]. Hence, chlorohexadecane (1.2eq.) and N,N-dimethylethanolamine (1eq.) were refluxed in absolute ethanol for 48h. Then, the solvent was removed under reduced pressure. The obtained solid was washed twice with diethyl ether to afford a white solid with a good yield (92%), m.p. 204°C. Other HEA16X (X=I−, Br−, HCO3 −, CH3SO3 − and CF3SO3 −) salts were prepared by ion-exchange in acetone or methanol from HEA16Cl and the appropriate alkaline salt, followed by solvent removal [47]. 2.3 Coupling reactions of epoxides and CO2 In a typical cycloaddition reaction, styrene oxide (SO; 17.5mmol), the catalyst (0.29mmol; SO/Cata=60), the GC internal standard (n-dodecane; 14.4mmol) and the solvent (40mL) were charged into a 160mL stainless-steel autoclave equipped with a mechanical stirrer and an electric heater. The autoclave was then purged with N2, the temperature was raised to 120°C and the system was pressurized with CO2 (P(CO2)=3, 7 or 15bar). The reaction mixture was stirred for 7 or 23h and the CO2 pressure was kept constant throughout the test. Catalyst lifetime tests were carried out without any separation step. At the end of each run, the reactor was depressurized and cooled down, and styrene oxide was re-introduced to replace the amount consumed earlier. The reaction was then re-started following the aforementioned procedure. Samples for GC–FID analysis were collected at different reaction times by means of a sampling probe, without stopping the reaction. Gas chromatography analyses were performed on a DELSI NERMAG DN200 instrument with a FID detector using a 30m long, 0.25mmi.d. and 0.25μm-thick capillary OPTIMA-5-MS column (MACHEREY-NAGEL). Styrene oxide (SO) and styrene carbonate (SC) amounts were obtained from their respective GC integration areas in the presence of the internal standard. Consumption of SO and formation of SC were monitored allowing the calculation of the following reaction descriptors: Styrene oxide ( SO ) conversion: % C = n ( SO, t = 0 ) - n ( SO, t ) n ( SO, t = 0 ) × 100 Styrene carbonate ( SC ) selectivity: % S = n ( SC, t ) n ( SO, t = 0 ) - n ( SO, t ) × 100 Styrene carbonate ( SC ) yield: % Y = n ( SC, t ) n ( SO,t = 0 ) × 100 Measurement accuracy for the catalytic results calculated on the basis of four injections per sample is 2%. 2.4 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations Geometry optimizations were performed at the hybrid density functional B3LYP level [53–55] with the GAUSSIAN 09 program [56]. The empirically dispersion-corrected functional B97D was also used [57]. The 6-31+G(d,p) basis set was used for all atoms. All the geometries were fully optimized without symmetry constraint. Transition state (TS) geometries were approached by a linear-transit procedure, while optimizing all other degrees of freedom. Full TS searches were started from the geometries corresponding to maxima along the linear-transit curves. Each TS displays only one negative eigenvalue according to a non-ambiguous saddle point. The imaginary frequency corresponds to the vector pointing in the direction of the specific reaction coordinate. Moreover, all the located TSs were confirmed to connect reactants and products by intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) calculations [58,59]. For each calculation, the solvation effects on the energies were accounted for the standard polarizable continuum model (PCM) [60,61] implemented in GAUSSIAN, the dielectric constant being the one of benzonitrile (ε =25.592). The nucleophilic character of the studied anions nucleophile in the presence of a cation was evaluated by the ω − index which has been recently proposed by Jaramillo et al. [62] in the framework of the Density Functional Theory of chemical reactivity (so-called Conceptual DFT). This index is defined as follows: ω - = 1 2 η Nu ( μ Nu - μ E ) 2 ( η Nu + η E ) 2 Here, μ Nu and μ E are the chemical potentials of the nucleophilic and electrophilic species whereas η Nu and η E are the hardness of the nucleophilic and electrophilic species, respectively. A large value of ω − indicates a good global nucleophilic character of the species Nu in the presence of an electrophile E. It is worth noting that μ and η can be practically evaluated from the Highest Occupied (HO) and the Lowest unoccupied (LU) Kohn-Sham Molecular Orbitals (MO) as follows: μ ≈1/2 (ε LUMO + ε HOMO) and η ≈(ε LUMO − ε HOMO), ε LUMO and ε HOMO being the energies of HOMO and LUMO orbitals, respectively (see values in Table SI.1) [63,64]. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Reaction conditions Using CTABr as the catalyst and styrene oxide as the substrate, preliminary tests allowed us to study the influence of the CO2 pressure and of the solvent nature on the catalytic activity and, therefore to define the most favorable reaction conditions for the following investigations. 3.1.1 Influence of the solvent N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) is a solvent widely used for the CO2 coupling reaction with epoxides [19,20,50,65,66]. In the present work, DMF, but also other high boiling point solvents, such as ethylbenzene, ethyl acetate and benzonitrile with different permittivity values (ε; i.e. ability to separate and stabilize the ions pairs) has been selected. In the initial part, styrene oxide (SO) carboxylation tests were performed at 120°C under 15bar of CO2 in the presence of CTABr. Results showed that the yield of styrene carbonate (SC) varied from 8% to 39% (Table 1 ). Better catalyst performances were obtained for solvents characterized by the highest ε values. Hence, DMF led to 85% styrene oxide conversion. This is not really surprising as amides are known to be good promoters of the carboxylation reaction according to Aresta et al. [69]. However, in the present work, the styrene carbonate selectivity (46%) was low in this solvent. A blank test performed in the absence of CTABr showed that DMF itself promoted the conversion of styrene oxide (48%) with no styrene carbonate formation. DMF was then excluded from further studies. Styrene oxide conversion and selectivity obtained in ethyl acetate were low (respectively 41% and 20%). Among the other solvents, benzonitrile led to the best selectivity (93%), as well as the best carbonate yield (35%). In addition, a blank test performed in benzonitrile in the absence of any catalyst showed almost no styrene oxide consumption, thus excluding the possibility of a catalytic contribution of this solvent. Based on all these results, benzonitrile was retained in the following part of this work. 3.1.2 Influence of the CO2 pressure The pressure may influence the diffusion of CO2 in the reaction mixture and the distribution of each reactant between the liquid and gas phases. The effect of this parameter on styrene oxide carboxylation was studied at 120°C in the presence of CTABr for constant pressures of CO2 set either to 3, 7 or 15bar (Table 2 ). According to the results, the pressure increase from 3 to 7bar led to an improvement of styrene oxide conversion from 67% to 83%. For higher pressure, the conversion seemed to be stable at approximately 80%. In parallel, the pressure increase from 3 to 15bar also induced an improvement of the selectivity of approximately 10% (from 82% to 93%). Thus, the best carbonate yield (73%) was achieved for the highest CO2 pressure (15bar) mainly as a result of an increased selectivity (93%). Based on the carbonate yield, the following investigations will be carried out at 15bar of CO2. There seems to be a pressure threshold over which no further considerable styrene oxide conversion is obtained [34,44,50,70]. In fact, while studying the catalytic activity of MOF-5 supported Bu4NBr, Song et al. [70] reported that the carbonate yield increased with pressure in the range of 4–10bar (at 50°C) and remained nearly unchanged with pressure in the range of 10–60bar. For pressures higher than 7bar (at 120°C) and with a different set of quaternary ammonium salts, Srivastava et al. [50] showed that there was no significant increase in the conversion and selectivity. 3.2 Catalyst structure and counter-anion effects on styrene carbonate production The various N-cetyl-N,N-dimethyl-N-(2-hydroxyethyl)ammonium salts (HEA16X, where X− is I−, Br−, Cl−, HCO3 −, CH3SO3 − (Ms) or CF3SO3 − (Tf)) have been evaluated in the styrene oxide/CO2 coupling tests, in benzonitrile at 120°C under 15bar of CO2. The results have been compared to those obtained in the presence of choline chloride and CTABr used as reference QAS (Table 3 ). In these conditions, only HEA16Tf did not show any activity for the substrate conversion. On the other hand, other hydroxyl-modified QAS led to styrene oxide conversions greater than with CTABr (Table 3, entry 7). 3.2.1 Influence of the polar head The comparison of the results obtained with CTABr (Table 3, entry 7) and HEA16Br (Table 3, entry 2) allowed to emphasize the influence of the structure of the polar head of the ammonium component (CH3 substituent in CTABr vs. CH2CH2OH one in HEA16Br). Hence, the presence of the hydroxyl chain in HEA16Br highly increased styrene oxide conversion (from 79% to 98%; Table 3, entries 2 and 7) as well as styrene carbonate yield (from 73% to 84%). On the other hand, the styrene carbonate selectivity presented a slight decrease from CTABr to HEA16Br (93% to 86%; Table 3, entries 2 and 7). This allowed us to propose that the interaction between the anion and the polar head is different in CTABr and HEA16Br leading probably in modifications of the nucleophilic character of the Br− anion. These results are not unexpected since modification of ionic liquids by introduction of OH groups has been described in the literature to be beneficial for the catalytic activity in the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides [32,46]. 3.2.2 Influence of the charge compensating anions The different compensation anions (Br−, I−, Cl−, HCO3 −, CF3SO3 − (Tf−) and CH3SO3 − (Ms−), Table 3), in the HEA16X series, also presented a significant influence on the catalytic activity (0<SO conversion<99%). Indeed, HEA16I (Table 3, entry 1) and HEA16Br (Table 3, entry 2) led to almost 100% SO conversion values while HEA16Tf showed no activity. In fact, styrene oxide conversion decreased in the following order: I− =Br− >HCO3 − >Ms− >Cl−. Considering the halogen series alone, the conversion values (I− =Br− >Cl−; Table 3, entries 1, 2 and 5) followed the order already reported in the literature for different other quaternary ammonium salts [27,34,35,50,52,71]. Poor nucleophilic anions such as HCO3 − (Table 3, entry 3) and Ms− (Table 3, entry 4) led to a higher styrene oxide conversion than Cl−, showing that the anion nucleophilicity is not the only important characteristic of the catalyst. It is noteworthy that HEA16Ms (Table 3, entry 4) led to 88% of styrene oxide conversion but styrene carbonate formation was not selective at all. In this case, phenylacetaldehyde was identified (GC–MS) to be the major secondary product (selectivity of about 25%) but the estimated GC carbon mass balance did not close (approximately 35% loss after 23h of reaction) probably as the result of the formation (through aldol condensation) of heavy side-products not detected by gas chromatography. 3.2.3 Influence of the chain length At last, the influence of the alkyl chain length was studied by comparing the activity of HEA1Cl (CH3-; Table 3, entry 6) and HEA16Cl (C16H33-; Table 3, entry 5). According to the data, both compounds led to similar styrene oxide conversion values (83% for HEA1Cl vs. 84% for HEA16Cl) and styrene carbonate selectivities (80% for HEA1Cl vs 75% for HEA16Cl). Thus, as already mentioned by Wang et al. [72] for tetraalkyl ammonium salts with C1 to C4 carbon substituents, the chain length of the ammonium component of the HEAnCl QAS considered here did not seem to have any significant influence on carbonate formation. On the other hand, literature also documents cases of symmetrical QAS whose longer alkyl chains (ranging from 1 to 4 [32] or even 16 carbon atoms [50] or 4 to 12 carbon atoms [52]) favor the catalytic activity. Comparisons are difficult because, depending on the paper, QAS were used either without any solvent [32,52] or with solvents [50] different from benzonitrile used here, or with much more drastic conditions [72]. 3.3 Kinetic studies Values of the apparent rate constants of styrene oxide conversion ( k SO ′ ) and of styrene carbonate formation ( k SC ′ ) have been evaluated for each catalyst. Typical curves for styrene oxide (SO) conversion and styrene carbonate (SC) selectivity versus time obtained using HEA16Br are presented in Fig. 2 . It is shown that the selectivity is approximately constant over the whole duration of the test. Then, it can be deduced that by-products come from a parallel reaction rather than by a successive pathway as schematized in Fig. 3 . Based on previous studies by North and Pasquale, [73], it has been firstly assumed that the reaction is of first order with respect to styrene oxide. In addition, bearing in mind that the reactor is constantly fed with 15bar of CO2, it is correct to presume that CO2 concentration is constant. The rate equation of styrene conversion can be thus expressed as follows in Eq. (1): (1) r = k SO ′ [ SO ] = - d [ SO ] dt in which k SO ′ = k [ CO 2 ] α where t is the reaction time in minutes, k SO ′ is the apparent first order rate constant in min−1 and [SO] is the styrene oxide concentration for a given time t. From the integration of Eq. (1), it was possible to obtain the following: (2) ln [ SO ] 0 [ SO ] = k SO ′ t In addition, SC selectivity can be considered as constant from which the following expression for the apparent rate constant of styrene consumption ( k SO ′ ) can be written as follows: (3) k SO ′ = k SC ′ + k B-P or by (4) k SO ′ = k SC ′ α SC where k SC ′ is the apparent rate constant of styrene carbonate formation, k B-P is the rate constant of by-product formation and α SC represents the styrene carbonate selectivity (average value) obtained for each catalyst. Fig. 4 shows that ln([SO]0/[SO]) versus time is linear in the case of HEA16Br. For all the catalysts, except for HEA16Ms, a linear relationship was also obtained (Figs. SI.1–SI.6, Supplementary material). The correlation coefficients were in the 0.93–0.99 range. Then, it can be concluded that, in agreement with the literature [22,71], the carboxylation reaction is of first order with respect to the concentration of styrene oxide, and that the apparent rate constants, k SO ′ and k SC ′ , can be used as activity parameters of the catalysts (Table 4 ). For HEA16Ms, the fact that styrene carbonate formation data do not fit with a first order kinetics is in good agreement with the occurrence of a non-identified parallel reaction as mentioned before. Of all the catalysts tested, HEA16I (Table 4, entry 1) and HEA16Br (Table 4, entry 2) were characterized by the highest reaction rates as well as conversion and selectivity values after 23h. Earlier in this study, it was shown that HEA16HCO3 (Table 3, entry 3) was as selective as HEA16I (Table 3, entry 1) and HEA16Br (Table 3, entry 2) for carbonate formation with a rather high SC yield (81%). However, the value of the reaction rate in the case of HEA16HCO3 (Table 4, entry 3) was only about the half of the ones obtained for HEA16I (Table 4, entry 1) and HEA16Br (Table 4, entry 2). Molar conversion of styrene oxide was superior by 10% after 23h in the case of HEA16HCO3 compared to HEA16Cl (Table 4, entry 4) but it turned out that HEA16HCO3 presents finally a styrene oxide conversion rate constant of the same order as HEA16Cl. So it seems that, from a kinetic point of view, halide anions are overall more efficient. Styrene oxide consumption and styrene carbonate formation rates were both about three times higher for the hydroxyl group containing HEA16Br catalyst (Table 4, entry 2) than for CTABr (Table 4, entry 7), even if this last one turned to be the most selective (Table 3, entry 7) of all the studied catalysts. 3.4 Catalyst lifetime The positive contribution of the hydroxyl group of the QAS polar head in terms of catalysis has been demonstrated by the higher values of the rate constants ( k SO ′ , k SC ′ ) obtained with HEA16Br compared to CTABr. However, stability is a very important quality for a catalyst. This was tested under homogeneous conditions, by re-filling the reaction mixture recovered after 23h in the case of HEA16Br with fresh styrene oxide without removing styrene carbonate and carrying out another test at 120°C and 15bar of CO2. Such procedure was repeated three times. According to Fig. 5 , the conversion and selectivity values measured for the first run were 97% and 86%, respectively. Such experiment allowed us to conclude that HEA16Br is a rather stable catalyst since conversion and selectivity values in the 2nd to the 4th runs were similar to those of the initial one. 3.5 Density functional theory (DFT) study The influence of the various quaternary ammonium salts on the reaction path and intermediates formed was thoroughly investigated by DFT. Such theoretical work provided an interesting support for the experimental data, affording a deeper understanding of the reaction process and the distinct interactions between the different components of the catalytic system. The first step of the theoretical study was the determination of a relevant system to be used for modeling the catalyst structure. It was notably important to choose an appropriate carbon chain length in the HEAnX and CTAnX ammonium groups in order to achieve a good compromise between the precision of results with respect to experimental data and the computational effort. Typical energetic and structural quantities were performed at the B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p) level of theory using different carbon chain lengths (n =1, 4, 8, 12), namely the ammonium group/compensation anion interaction energy, the distance between the ammonium and the compensation anion and the molecular dipole of the optimized HEAnX and CTAnX ammonium structures in the absence of the epoxide. Chloride and bromide salts were selected. HEAnX and CTAnX ammonium structures (n =8, 12) were also optimized at the B97D/6-31+G(d,p) level of theory. All these results were gathered and are presented in Table 5 . Since catalytic activities of HEA16Br and HEA16I were very similar and due to the high number of electrons in iodide, calculations with this counterion have not been performed, to avoid superfluous calculation time. According to the collected data in Table 5, the interaction energies and the dipole moment values do not significantly change for chain lengths longer than 8 carbon atoms and thus, whatever the nature of the anion (Br− vs Cl−) or the nature of the polar head (HEAn vs CTAn). All the interaction energies have been found lower than 10kcalmol− 1, what seems to be weak for an anion-cation interaction. However, a CCSD(T)/6-311++G(2d,2p) single-point calculation using the B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p) optimized geometry gives an interaction energy of −7.31kcalmol− 1 for the HEA1-Cl structure. Thus, this high-level ab initio calculation supports the result obtained from B3LYP (−6.55kcalmol− 1, see Table 5). Apart from this calculation, the robustness of our B3LYP results was evaluated by changing the functional for the B97D ones. At first, we notice that for the HEAnX (n =8, 12) optimized structures, the results are not much modified (see Table 5). For example, the difference between B3LYP and B97D is only of 0.011Å for the equilibrium distance OHBr. Likewise, B3LYP and B97D provide geometries in fairly good agreement for the CTAnBr structures, but interaction energies calculated at the B3LYP level appear underestimated by 2kcalmol− 1. However, more importantly, are the trends drawn from the numbers, whatever the retained functional. (1) These findings allow to continue the theoretical investigation with a smaller chain of 8 carbon atoms (HEA8X or CTA8X), as opposed to the real chain of 16 carbon atoms (HEA16X or CTA16X). (2) The presence of the polar head leads to a better stabilization of the anion with the ammonium and thus, could have an influence on the catalytic efficiency (see next section). 3.6 Influence of the polar head of the ammonium group The optimized structures of both HEA8Br and CTA8Br at the B3LYP/6-31+G(d,p) level are displayed in Fig. 6 . In the presence of the hydroxyethyl group (HEA8Br), the anion (i.e. Br−) is involved in a hydrogen bond with the hydrogen atom of the OH function (Fig. 6a) whereas, for sole alkyl groups, the anion seems to be electrostatically bonded to the positively charged ammonium (Fig. 6b) as already proposed by Wang et al. [43] in the case of tetraalkyl ammonium halides. Such interaction was also observed whatever the anion studied (Br−, Cl−, HCO3 −, Ms− and Tf−) as shown by the optimized geometry of all the calculated structures in Fig. SI.7 of the Supplementary material. The hydrogen bond formation in HEA8Br leads to a stronger cation–anion interaction, represented by a larger interaction energy between the ammonium group and the anion (−7.05kcalmol− 1, see Table 5, entry 3) than for CTA8Br (−4.77kcalmol− 1, see Table 5, entry 11). The strength of the cation–anion bond is also illustrated by the shorter cation–anion distance for HEA8Br (2.30Å) compared to CTA8Br (4.25Å), as presented in Fig. 6. To understand the role of the polar head structure on the reaction mechanism, the geometry of the reactants, catalysts and transition states was optimized in a probable reaction pathway, presented in Fig. 7 a for HEA8Br. The relative energies of these optimized structures are reported with respect to the energy of the initial structure resulting from the interaction between the epoxide and the catalyst (A-Br in Fig. 7a). Note that before CO2 is entered into the reaction system (i.e. for A-Br, TS1-Br and B-Br), these relative energies are reported with respect to the sum of the energy of the initial structure and the energy of a single optimized CO2 molecule. The first transition state (TS1-Br), corresponds to the nucleophilic attack of the compensation anion onto the epoxide leading to the opening of the oxirane ring and the stabilization of the resulting negative species by the ammonium salt (B-Br). Then, reaction occurs between CO2 and the oxy anion of the ring-opened epoxide giving a new transition state (TS-CO2 in Fig. 7a) characterized by a very low activation energy (0.3kcalmol− 1). The latter result was checked by changing the B3LYP functional for B97D. We found also a very small activation energy of only 0.2kcalmol− 1. Thus, regarding these findings, this step is not expected to have any influence on the catalytic activity. In the following, the TS-CO2 species evolve to a more stable carbonate (state C-Br in Fig. 7a). Finally, a last transition state corresponding to the ring-closure of the epoxide and the elimination of the compensation anion (TS2-Br in Fig. 7a) is reached allowing the formation of the final product represented by D-Br in Fig. 7a. In the mechanisms involving functionalized ionic liquids described in the literature [29,45,74], hydroxyl groups are both involved in the activation of the epoxide opening and in the stabilization of the negatively charged intermediate formed after CO2 incorporation. These results were supported by DFT calculations in the case of the catalytic system composed of glycerol and KI [75], but also for the combination of various hydrogen bond donors (i.e. phenol or hydroxyphenol and water) and nBu4NX (X=Br or I−) [31,40]. So, it seems that when the hydrogen-bond promoter (glycerol, phenol, hydroxyphenol or H2O) is initially separated from the anion (I− in KI or nBu4NI and Br− in nBu4NBr), the most favorable path starts with the nucleophilic attack of the anion on the epoxide, already activated by an interaction with the OH group. On the other hand, in the case of the series of quaternary ammonium salts bearing a OH group studied here, the most stable initial state corresponds, according to our calculations, to the interaction described for A-Br (Fig. 7a) and, not to the interaction between the OH group and the epoxide. The hydrogen bond between the OH and the epoxide only occurs after the nucleophilic attack (state B-Br), when the hydrogen promoter and the nucleophile are already dissociated as favored by solvents with high ε values. This discrepancy is likely due to the fact that in our case the hydrogen bond donor is borne by the ammonium polar head. However, it can be noted that the energy profile calculated by Wang et al. [31] for the nBu4NBr/water system is relatively closed to the ones proposed in this study. In the absence of hydrogen bond promoters (e.g. with CTA8Br, Fig. 7b), the chemical intermediates are stabilized differently (see optimized geometries in the Fig. 7b). Like for HEA8Br, the first transition state (TS1-Br; Fig. 7b) corresponds to the nucleophilic attack of Br− provided by CTA8Br and the ring-opening of the epoxide. However, the resulting B-Br intermediate is less stable (16.1kcalmol− 1) than in the case of HEA8Br (9.8kcalmol− 1). Electrostatic interactions between the ammonium and the negatively charged oxygen of the opened epoxide (see optimized conformations of B-Br in Fig. 7b) seem to be less efficient than hydrogen bonding between the same oxygen atom and the hydrogen of the hydroxyl group as described for HEA8Br. After this, the reaction between CO2 and B-Br leads directly to C-Br. No energy saddle-point was found for the TSCO2-Br transition state in the presence of CTA8Br. Thus this step proceeds via barrierless reaction pathways in agreement with a previous work of Wang et al. [31] obtained with a similar system nBu4NBr/water. In C-Br, the negative charge of the newly formed carbonate is again differently compensated in the presence or absence of the OH function: by hydrogen bond in the case of HEA8Br or by electrostatic interaction with CTA8Br. The potential energy surface profiles (Fig. 8 ) show that the C-Br intermediate formed in the presence of HEA8Br is more stabilized (−9.14kcalmol− 1) than that obtained with CTA8Br (−7.66kcalmol− 1). The rest of the reaction mechanism is very similar (same states with similar energies), and the only difference comes again from the way the different species are stabilized (electrostatic interaction vs hydrogen bond). According to our experimental results (Tables 3 and 4), the use of HEA16Br instead of CTABr induces a strong improvement of styrene oxide conversion (from 79% to 98%) without deep modification of the styrene carbonate selectivity (86% for HEA16Br vs 93% for CTABr). Such variation can be tentatively attributed to the activation energies of TS1-Br and to the difference in the energies of B-Br intermediates (see Fig. 8). Similar values for the activation energies were also found at the B97D/6-31+G(d,p) level of theory. Indeed, using HEA8Br and CTA8Br, activation energies were respectively determined to be 18.7kcalmol− 1 and 18.0kcalmol− 1. Moreover, for both catalysts, the energy of the B-Br state is relatively high in comparison with that of the initial state (A-Br), indicating that the formation of B-Br is not thermodynamically favored. However, in the case of HEA8Br, the energy of B-Br is much lower than for CTA8Br (9.8 vs 16.1kcalmol− 1). Thus, the trend which emerges from our calculations suggests that the catalyst bearing the CH2CH2OH substituent is more efficient and therefore could explain the higher activity observed for HEA16Br. 3.6.1 Compensation anion DFT calculations were also performed in order to evaluate the influence of the anions (Fig. 9 ; Br−, Cl−, HCO3 −, Ms−, Tf−). According to the mechanism proposed for HEAnX compounds, both the nucleophilicity of the compensation anion and the ability of the ammonium (HEAn+) to stabilize the negatively charged species affect the reactivity of the catalyst. Since the first proposed reaction step (energetic level of TS1-X) corresponds to the nucleophilic attack of the compensation anion on the epoxide, it was important to look at the nucleophilic character of the studied anions in the presence of the HEAn+ cation. Values of the ω − index were calculated (Table 6 ) indicating the following ascending order of nucleophilicity: Tf− <Ms− <HCO3 − <Cl− ≈Br− . As expected, HEA8Tf stands out from the others (Fig. 9) with its highest activation energy for the first transition state (TS1: 33.3kcalmol− 1) and lowest stability of the B-X intermediate (21.2kcalmol− 1). Even more, it was the only catalyst presenting a positive relative energy for C-X (2.7kcalmol− 1). In other words, it appears that the C-Tf intermediate, issued from the reaction between CO2 and the ring-opened epoxide, is not thermodynamically favored when compared to its analogs bearing other compensation anions. In fact, the activation energies related to the first transition state (TS1-X values from Fig. 9) are ordered as follows: Tf− >Ms− >Cl− >HCO3 − >Br−. According to our theoretical calculations, it appears clearly that there is no strict correlation between the nucleophilicity and the activation energy of the first transition state TS1-X. Discrepancies are especially observed for Cl− and HCO3 − anions. Experimentally, HEA16HCO3 was effectively a better catalyst than HEA16Cl whereas Cl− is, at the same time, much more nucleophilic (ω − ( HEA8)(Cl−)=0.42 and ω − ( HEA8)(HCO3 −)=0.25, see Table 6). The fact that HCO3 − is one of the conjugate bases of CO2 and that it can be considered as a CO2 “reservoir” led us to further investigate its reactivity toward styrene oxide. A more favorable mechanism pathway specific to HEA8HCO3 is proposed in Fig. 10 . In line with the previous proposal (Fig. 9), the reaction still starts with the nucleophilic attack of HCO3 − on the epoxide (TS1-HCO3′). In this case, a new intermediate species (B-HCO3′) much more stable (−19.4kcalmol− 1) than B-HCO3 (4.0kcalmol− 1) and all the aforementioned B-X species (Fig. 9) are obtained as the result of the consecutive transfer of the hydrogen brought by HCO3 − due to its proximity with the oxygen atom of the opened epoxide. Then, ring closure of the carbonate would occur with the simultaneous transfer of an OH substituent issued from the opened epoxide (TS-CO2′) to external CO2 leading to the regeneration of the catalyst and the formation of D-HCO3′. It has to be noted that this mechanism involves two transition states instead of three. The use of an ammonium hydrogenocarbonate as catalyst precursor for epoxide coupling with CO2 has been described only very recently [76]. Ema et al used especially tetrabutylammonium hydrogenocarbonate but did not compare its performance to those involving the usual nucleophiles. In their DFT study the authors suggested several mechanism assumptions to explain the catalytic efficiency of HCO3 −. The above proposed mechanism (Fig. 10) differs from that of Ema et al in that the assumption was made here that the attack of the epoxide by the hydrogenocarbonate ion is coupled to a prototropy (H migration from HCO3 − on to the negatively charged O atom coming from the ring opening of the epoxide). The resulting B-HCO3′ species take advantage of the stabilization effect of H bonds involving the hydroxyethyl substituent carried by the polar head of the ammonium ion (here HEA16). Although Br− and Cl− are characterized by approximately the same ω − index values (nucleophilicity), HEA8Br seems to be responsible of a slightly better stabilization of the reaction intermediates and gives slightly lower activation energies for the transition states. Actually, the biggest differences between the reaction paths with HEA8Br and HEA8Cl correspond to strong discrepancies in B-Br et B-Cl energies and in the related activation energies leading to TS1-Br and TS1-Cl. Hence, it is conceivable that the stabilization of the B-X intermediates induced by H-bonding between the OH group on the polar head and the negatively charged oxygen atom derived from the epoxide is less in the case of B-Cl compared to B-Br due to some competition of O and Cl (also characterized by a high electronegativity) atoms toward H bonding in the first intermediate. Regarding the effect of the compensation anions for a similar chemical pathway (Fig. 9), the relative stability of B-X and C-X intermediates increases in the order Tf− <Cl− ≈Ms− <Br−, which corresponds also to the order for styrene oxide conversion found in the experimental part of this work (Br− >Ms− ≈Cl− ≫Tf−). As far as the selectivity toward styrene carbonate is concerned, the evolution of the experimental results is more in line with the activation energy for the TS1-X transition states. As a matter of fact, the styrene carbonate selectivity turned out to be higher when the nucleophilic attack is easier (i.e. the lower is the activation energy for TS1-X). 3.6.2 Effect of the chain length The comparison of the energy profiles obtained with HEA8Cl and HEA1Cl (Fig. 11 ) finally allows to conclude that the chain length shows almost no influence on the catalyst performances of the QAS. This behavior is supported by the similar anion-cation interaction energies obtained in Table 5 (entries 5 and 7) for these two ammonium salts. The lack of influence of the cation size on the catalytic activity has already been reported in the DFT literature for tetraalkyl quaternary ammoniums [43] but this was demonstrated with a much smaller variation of the number of carbon atoms (from 2 to 4). Such theoretical results obtained with HEA1Cl and HEA8Cl are in good agreement with the experimental measurements. Again, the optimum values of styrene oxide conversions and SC selectivities were correlated with the lowest energy values of the B-X or C-X states and of the TS1-X transition states, respectively. Indeed, HEA1Cl and HEA16Cl gave rise to the same styrene oxide conversion (i.e. 83–84%) as well as approximately the same energies for the B-X and C-X states (see Fig. 11, HEA1Cl and HEA8Cl). In addition, SC selectivity was slightly higher with HEA1Cl compared to HEA16Cl (i.e. 80% vs 75%) in agreement with a slightly lower energy of the first transition state TS1-Cl in the case of HEA1Cl (23.5kcalmol− 1) compared to HEA8Cl (25.9kcalmol− 1). 4 Conclusions Quaternary ammonium salts with 2-hydroxyethyl substituents (HEA16X), i.e. N,N-dimethyl-N-cetyl-N-(2-hydroxyethyl) ammonium (HEA16+) associated with different counter-anions (X−), were synthesized and tested, for the first time, as organocatalysts in the cycloaddition of CO2 to styrene oxide. Not only halide ions, as reported in most other reports, but also mesylate, triflate and hydrogenocarbonate ions were considered here in order to carry out a more systematic experimental and theoretical study (effect of counterion, polar head). Undoubtedly, the compensation anions had a prominent influence on the catalytic performances of the quaternary ammonium salts (QAS). With the exception of triflate ions, all the QAS compounds were characterized by reasonable catalytic activities at 120°C and under 15bar of CO2. Tests performed with HEA16Br showed that these catalysts could be recycled up to 4 consecutive runs with no significant loss of activity. The detailed kinetic study of the styrene oxide/CO2 coupling reaction provided an additional contribution (cf rate constant values) to those of other groups who showed previously the beneficial effect of hydroxyl functions borne by quaternary ammonium salts themselves or using additives. Clearly, DFT calculations pointed out the stabilizing role of hydrogen bonds involving the hydroxyl group of the ammonium cation (HEA+), especially on the first reaction intermediate (case of HEA16Br vs. CTABr). Correlations could be drawn between the stability of the first reaction intermediate and high values of the conversion rate as well as between low activation energy values of the first step and high cyclic carbonate selectivity. Careful studies of the initial structures of the different ammonium salts emphasized strong interactions between the OH groups and the nucleophiles (X−) inducing effects on the ranking of the expected nucleophilic reactivity of the anions and preventing the pre-activation of the epoxide by these OH groups in the first step as described by other research teams. According to us, this justifies a priori that the working conditions, although improved compared to those involving tetraalkylammonium salts, remain drastic compared to those in which the H donor is independent of the ammonium salt. Among all studied salts, HEA16HCO3 turned out to be as active as HEA16Cl while the nucleophilic forces of HCO3 − and Cl− anions established by DFT in this context are particularly unfavorable to HCO3 −. In the case of HEA16HCO3, DFT calculations indicated that CO2 inserted into the styrene carbonate comes from the hydrogenocarbonate ion and that HCO3 − can be regenerated emphasizing its catalytic role. In addition, it has been shown that a particularly stable first intermediate, compared to those formed with the other counter-anions, may be envisaged due to the concomitant migration of the acid proton of the HOC(O)O-group, itself in interaction with the hydroxyl group of QAS, onto the oxygen of the opened epoxide. coredata.dc:description: Among industrial applications of CO2, the formation of cyclic carbonates from epoxides offers relevant chemical potentialities. Here, various N,N-dimethyl-N-cetyl-N-(2-hydroxyethyl)ammonium salts (HEA16X) associated with different counter-anions (X−) have been investigated as catalysts of the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide to styrene oxide. Most of these salts were characterized by reasonable catalytic activities in benzonitrile at 120°C and under 15bar of CO2 compared to choline chloride and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide. The influence of three parameters has been studied: (i) the polar head group, (ii) the anion (I−, Br−, Cl− for halogens and HCO3 −, mesylate (Ms−), triflate (Tf−)) in the HEA16X series, as well as (iii) the chain length. The higher conversion and selectivity obtained with HEA16Br, compared to CTABr, pointed out the beneficial contribution of the hydroxylated polar head. The role of the compensation anion or more exactly of its nucleophilicity on the catalyst activity was also shown. However, unexpected results with HCO3 −, affording styrene oxide conversions up to 95% (better than with HEA16Cl), were also obtained. DFT calculations supported the beneficial influence of the 2-hydroxyethyl substituent and the unexpected reactivity of the ammonium hydrogenocarbonate, HEA16HCO3. The reaction profiles allowed to draw some correlations (i) between styrene oxide conversion and the relative energy of the first intermediate and (ii) between the styrene carbonate selectivity and the energy of the first transition state. A new and original mechanism was also proposed for the reaction catalyzed by ammonium hydrogenocarbonate.
coredata.dc:title: Experimental and theoretical evidences of the influence of hydrogen bonding on the catalytic activity of a series of 2-hydroxy substituted quaternary ammonium salts in the styrene oxide/CO2 coupling reaction
